channel.title: dbcls news - Articles
channel.description: Database Center for Life Science (DBCLS) forms a base for integrating databases in life science field. Positioning itself as a specialized institution to provide biological databases and related services, DBCLS integrates and maintains biological databases mainly within Japan, conducts R&D of information technology and develops new services to enhance usability.

item.title: The June 2019 issue of Genomics & Informatics was published as a special issue on the 5th Biomedical Linked Annotation Hackathon (BLAH5).
item.description:
The June 2019 issue of Genomics & Informatics was published as a special issue on the 5th Biomedical Linked Annotation Hackathon (BLAH5).

  • Genomics & Informatics, Volume 17, Issue 2, June 2019

item.title: A paper “Split4Blank: Maintaining consistency while improving efficiency of loading RDF data with blank nodes” was published in PLOS ONE.
item.description: A paper “Split4Blank: Maintaining consistency while improving efficiency of loading RDF data with blank nodes” was published in PLOS ONE. Dr. Atsuko Yamaguchi and Yasunori Yamamoto from DBCLS have contributed to this work.

item.title: A paper “Accumulating computational resource usage of genomic data analysis workflow to optimize cloud computing instance selection” was published in GigaScience.
item.description: A paper “Accumulating computational resource usage of genomic data analysis workflow to optimize cloud computing instance selection” was published in GigaScience. Dr. Tazro Ohta from DBCLS have contributed to the work by development of the system and the RNA-Seq workflow comparison analysis using the system.

item.title: A paper “Cancerous phenotypes associated with hypoxia-inducible factors are not influenced by the volatile anesthetic isoflurane in renal cell carcinoma” was published in PLOS ONE.
item.description: A paper “Cancerous phenotypes associated with hypoxia-inducible factors are not influenced by the volatile anesthetic isoflurane in renal cell carcinoma” was published in PLOS ONE. Dr. Hidemasa Bono from DBCLS have contributed to this work in the sequence analysis of transcriptome data.
